claims.claim_text: Data Structures are specialized formats used to organize, store, and manage data in a computer system. A common example is the stack, which follows the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO) and uses push and pop operations for adding and removing items respectively.
claims.top_evidence:
NOTES:
Stack A stack is a linear data structure which is used to store data items and follows the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO). First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: A stack is a data container that follows the rule "Last In, First Out" (LIFO). Items are added to or removed from the top of the stack using operations called push (adding) and pop (removing).
claims.top_evidence:
NOTES:
Stack A stack is a linear data structure which is used to store data items and follows the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO). First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: The Principle of Stack in computer science means that the last item added to a stack is the first one to be removed. This linear data structure follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) rule, with push and pop operations being used for adding and removing items respectively.
